Award.AbstractNarration:
Entanglement, the unique property of quantum mechanics that prevents the description of a system by just looking at the properties of its individual components, is a centerpiece in current research in diverse areas of physics spanning from quantum information science to condensed matter physics to quantum field theory. The main objective of this research is to understand the role of entanglement in the description of the quantum nature of space-time. This works investigates fundamental puzzles in theoretical physics such as the description of the primordial state of the universe and the fate of information in black hole evaporation. The focus is on universal aspects of space-time entanglement that can provide valuable insights for any theory of quantum gravity.

At the Planck scale new quantum effects that go beyond Einstein's general relativity are expected to dominate. Loop quantum gravity is one of the leading candidate theories for describing the physics in these regimes. In this theory, space-time has a granular structure that arises as a foam-like excitation of a topologically invariant vacuum. From this perspective, space-time is made of 'elementary constituents' and, as in condensed matter physics, it can have different quantum phases. The main open problem is to identify the quantum phase that describes our smooth extended space-time. A set of techniques that were recently developed in condensed matter physics will be used to study the amount of entanglement between quantum geometry degrees of freedom. This research will directly address the question of the quantum nature of space-time. The results of this research on entangled-network states will provide the basis for extracting physical properties of space-time states in quantum gravity. Three directions will be investigated. The first regards the Minkowski space-time state where the entangled-network state is obtained via a variational ansatz for the minimization of the ADM energy. The second direction regards the use of entangled-network states in quantum cosmology, the study of entanglement near classical singularities, and the thermalization time of subsystems in the de Sitter expansion phase. The third direction regards black hole space-times, the relation between entanglement entropy and black hole entropy, and the dynamics of entanglement entropy in the evaporation process.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project lies at the interface between general relativity, quantum field theory and thermodynamics. It investigates the role played by entanglement in quantum gravity, with the goal of determining what is the quantum nature of spacetime. The three main outcomes of this project are:

a. Entanglement and the architecture of spacetime. In condensed matter physics, the ground state of a many-body system is characterized by its quantum correlations and entanglement structure. In quantum gravity, a related conjecture (known as the Bianchi-Myers architecture conjecture) was proposed in 2014: quantum states which describe a semiclassical spacetime with small quantum fluctuations are characterized by an area law for the entanglement entropy. This conjecture has resulted in a concrete construction of squeezed vacua in loop quantum gravity which are characterized by their entanglement structure. The techniques involved provide also new mathematical tools for quantum geometry computations. The new class of squeezed vacua obtained give us better control of the semiclassical regime of the theory, a needed step in order to extract robust theoretical predictions from loop quantum gravity.

b. Black hole evaporation and the information puzzle. Because of entanglement and Hawking radiation, black holes are hot objects with a huge entropy. Information-theoretic principles imply that the entropy of radiation from old black holes differs from the one from young black holes of the same mass, the time-scale being set by the Page time. This is an out-of-equilibrium phenomenon where small quantum effects cumulate over long times and result in new phenomena which cannot be predicted by perturbative semiclassical methods. Novel field-theoretical methods to describe this regime have been developed since 2014. In particular a new relation (known as the Bianchi-Smerlak formula) has been found which connects the energy-flux of the black holes's radiation at one time to its entanglement entropy at previous times. The results of work in this direction is to provide the foundations for robust derivations of black hole's entanglement evolution beyond the Page time, and can provide predictions for the new effects that are expected to arise in this late time regime.

c. Primordial state of the universe and primordial entanglement. The standard inflationary paradigm posits that, at the beginning of the phase of exponential expansion which preceded the hot big bang, small quantum fluctuations of the spacetime geometry and of the inflaton were in a state with highly-entangled fluctuations at short distances. While phenomenologically successful, this assumption neglects quantum gravity effects. Standard results on the decoupling of perturbations close to cosmological singularities in general relativity suggest in fact that the quantum gravity state was un-entangled at short distances, instead of being highly-entangled. The contributions of this line of research are twofold: First of all, we determined a mechanism responsible for the growth of entanglement in the pre-inflationary phase and showed that, by the onset of inflation, all the quantum correlations already constrained by observations are produced even if inflation lasted only the minimum number of e-foldings. Secondly, and most importantly, we provided the basis for investigations aimed at providing detailed predictions of specific imprints that such entanglement structure can leave in cosmological observables, such as the anisotropy correlations in the cosmic microwave background and the density correlations in the large-scale structure of the universe, which are already accessible today.

 

Broader impacts of this project involve the identification of applications to other physical systems of the new mathematical methods developed in the context of quantum gravity:

d. Entanglement and thermalization. Entanglement plays a central role in our current understanding of thermalization in isolated quantum systems. Recently, these ideas have had a profound impact in the study of condensed matter systems, both at the theoretical and the experimental level. On the other hand, black hole evaporation and the primordial universe can be considered as isolated quantum systems undergoing a thermalization process. This conceptual and technical relation provided an opportunity for cross-fertilization between condensed matter physics and gravitational physics, and resulted in the first calculation of the Page curve for energy eigenstates of a many-body quantum system.
